context:
Description The gig economy is composed of corporate entities workers and consumers
Us Canada Employment Code defines the gig economy as activity where people earn income providing on-demand work services or goods noting that the activity is often facilitated through a digital platform such as a mobile app or website and earnings may be in the form of cash property goods or virtual currency
According to the Fair Work Ombudsman the digital platforms or marketplaces connect individual service providers directly to customers for a fee
evidence:
Corporate entities workers and consumers are part of the gig economy.
The gig economy is defined by the Internal Revenue Service as activity where people earn income providing on-demand work services or goods through a digital platform and earnings may be in the form of cash property goods or virtual currency.
The digital platforms connect service providers directly to their customers for a fee.

context:
Freelancers often face challenges with clients claiming ownership over creative work without proper compensation or acknowledgment
A 2022 survey conducted by Freelancers Union in partnership with the Authors Guild and other organizations found that 62% of freelancers in New York had experienced wage theft at least once in their careers with 53% reporting losses of up to $10000 from nonpayment
Legal developments like The Labor ##s continue to influence the gig economy aiming to reclassify some design freelancers as employees ensuring legal protections like minimum wage and benefits
Among the common types of digital platforms in the gig economy are those to provide ridesharing services food or package delivery services crafts and handmade item marketplaces on-demand labor and repair services property and space rentals
A study completed in 2016 by Lawrence Katz and Alan Krueger showed an increase in gig workers freelancers and independent contractors of 50 percent between 2005 and 2015
evidence:
There are challenges with clients claiming ownership over creative work.
According to a survey conducted by the Freelancers Union in partnership with the Authors Guild and other organizations, over half of New York's freelancers have experienced wage theft at some point in their careers.
The gig economy is trying to reclassify some designers as employees in order to make sure they have legal protections.
Among the common types of digital platforms in the gig economy are those to provide food, package delivery, crafts, and handmade item marketplaces.
Between 2005 and 2015 there was a 50 percent increase in the number of gig workers.

cp: Legal developments like Californias AB5 law continue to influence the gig economy aiming to reclassify some design freelancers as employees ensuring legal protections like minimum wage and benefits
Legal developments like The Labor ##s continue to influence the gig economy aiming to reclassify some design freelancers as employees ensuring legal protections like minimum wage and benefits

context:
Legal developments like Californias AB5 law continue to influence the gig economy aiming to reclassify some design freelancers as employees ensuring legal protections like minimum wage and benefits
Among the common types of digital platforms in the gig economy are those to provide ridesharing services food or package delivery services crafts and handmade item marketplaces on-demand labor and repair services property and space rentals
A study completed in 2016 by David Smith and Alan Krueger showed an increase in gig workers freelancers and independent contractors of 50 percent between 2005 and 2015
These jobs accounted for 94 percent of all employment growth in the United States during those ten years
As of 2021 16% of all adults in the United States had earned income through the gig economy with higher levels of gig economy experience having accrued to younger demographics according to the Pew Research Center
evidence:
The gig economy is trying to reclassify some designers as employees in order to make sure they have legal protections.
Among the common types of digital platforms in the gig economy are those to provide food, package delivery, crafts, and handmade item marketplaces.
Between 2005 and 2015 there was a 50 percent increase in the number of gig workers.
During those ten years, these jobs accounted for 94 percent of all employment growth.
As of 2021, 16% of adults in the United States had earned income through the gig economy, with higher levels of gig economy experience having accrued to younger people.

context:
The size of the gig economy depends on how one defines it and whose statistics one uses
The Bureau of National Standards uses the term electronically mediated work to represent short jobs or tasks that workers find through websites or mobile apps that both connect them with customers and arrange payment for the tasks
A work published in September 2018 determined that such work accounted for 10 percent of total employment in May 2017
evidence:
The size of the gig economy depends on a number of factors.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics uses the term electronically mediated work to represent short jobs that workers find through websites or mobile apps that connect them with customers and arrange payment for the tasks.
In May of last year, 10 percent of total employment was accounted for by such work.

context:
The size of the gig economy depends on how one defines it and whose statistics one uses
The Bureau of Labor Statistics uses the term electronically mediated work to represent short jobs or tasks that workers find through websites or mobile apps that both connect them with customers and arrange payment for the tasks
A work published in May 2018 determined that such work accounted for 10 percent of total employment in May 2017
At about the same time the Government Accountability Office stated that the definition and the data source variations support claims from below 5% to over one-third of the labor force engage in non-traditional employment
evidence:

The Bureau of Labor Statistics uses the term electronically mediated work to represent short jobs that workers find through websites or mobile apps that connect them with customers and arrange payment for the tasks.
In May of last year, 10 percent of total employment was accounted for by such work.
The definition and data source variations support claims that up to one-third of the labor force engage in non-traditional employment, according to the Government Accountability Office.

evidence:
The Bureau of Labor Statistics uses the term electronically mediated work to represent short jobs that workers find through websites or mobile apps that connect them with customers and arrange payment for the tasks.
In May of last year, 10 percent of total employment was accounted for by such work.
The definition and data source variations support claims that up to one-third of the labor force engage in non-traditional employment, according to the Government Accountability Office.
The gig economy is a $1 trillion sector of the US economy, according to Forbes.
The gig economy is growing regardless of the definition used.

context:
As of November 2022 the 10 largest gig economy companies by market capitalization included Intuit tax preparation software PayPal online payments Airbnb hosting marketplace Uber ride-sharing and Shopify e-commerce
Other leading companies include Lyft OnlyFans content-subscription service DoorDash and Instacart
